sameAnalysis.word_list: car, bus, truck, lorry, coach, automobile, jeep, carriage, waggon
means: car ： 多指乘坐人的小汽车或轿车。
bus ： 一般指公共汽车或大型客车。
truck与lorry同义，都指卡车或货车，前者为美国用词，后者用于英国。
coach ： 原义指四轮马车，现指轿式汽车，长途公共汽车，还可指火车设有卧铺的车厢。
jeep ： 吉普车，指一种小型轻便、适合在崎岖路面或野外使用的车子。
carriage ： 指马车，两匹或两匹以上马拉的四轮马。
waggon ： 指四轮运货马车或牛车，也指铁路的无盖货车。

stems_affixes.value_cn: 汽车, 小汽车, 车辆, 客车, [铁]车厢
stems_affixes.word_buile: car装载,负担→n.汽车, 小汽车, 车辆, 客车, [铁]车厢
car车+eer人→愿意为车辆经过的道路→人所经历的路程→事业, 生涯

stems_affixes.value_cn: 船货, [车、船、飞机等运输的]货物
stems_affixes.word_buile: car装载,负担+go→n.船货, [车、船、飞机等运输的]货物

stems_affixes.value_cn: 马车, 客车, 运费
stems_affixes.word_buile: carry携带, 运送+age物品→马车, 客车

stems_affixes.value_cn: 运送者, 邮递员, 带菌者
stems_affixes.word_buile: carry携带, 运送+er人→carrier运送者, 带菌者
car装载,负担+t→n.大车, 手推车

stems_affixes.value_cn: 携带, 运送, 支持, 支撑, 传送, 意味
stems_affixes.word_buile: car装载,负担+ry→携带, 运送

entry.def: A car is a motor vehicle with room for a small number of passengers.

example.ex: He had left his tickets in his car...

entry.def: A car is one of the separate sections of a train.

entry.def: Railway carriages are called cars when they are used for a particular purpose.

means.word_mean: 1. 4-wheeled motor vehicle; usually propelled by an internal combustion engine;

sentences.sentence: "he needs a car to get to work"

means.word_mean: 2. a wheeled vehicle adapted to the rails of railroad;
3. a conveyance for passengers or freight on a cable railway;

sentences.sentence: "they took a cable car to the top of the mountain"

means.word_mean: 4. car suspended from an airship and carrying personnel and cargo and power plant
5. where passengers ride up and down;

sentences.sentence: "the car was on the top floor"

derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English (in the general sense 'wheeled vehicle'): from Old Northern French carre, based on Latin carrum, carrus, of Celtic origin

Sentence.sentence: an accelerating speeda shift to city centersa new focus on small citiesan ever-increasing demandPeople can live without private cars.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: Consider trying to remember where you parked your car in the same car park you were at a week earlier.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: Tom Moses, who works at a nearby national park, noticed a brown patch on the back of the car after the owner parked it to do some shopping.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: Thousands of bees left a town after landing on the back of a car when their queen got stuck in its boot.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: The man in the Google vehicle reported that he assumed the bus would slow down to let the car out, and so he did not switch to the manual mode.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: Still, 60% of drivers would like to get some kind of self-driving feature, such as automatic braking or self-parking the next time they buy a new car.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: One of Google’s self-driving cars crashed into a bus in California last month.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: On February 14th, the self-driving car, travelling at 2 miles per hour, pulled out in front of a public bus going 15 miles per hour.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: It is not the first time one of Google’s famed self-driving cars has been involved in a crash, but it may be the first time it has caused one.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: He also believes they will be more likely to trust selfdriving cars as they become more familiar with features such as automatic braking or parking.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: Auto makers and tech companies are working hard to offer the first true selfdriving car.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: Advocates of selfdriving cars argue they will be safer than in cars driven by humans because they wouldn’t get distracted or drive when tired.
Sentence.come: 出自-2017年6月听力原文

Sentence.sentence: Whereas older generations are sometimes reluctant to adopt new technologies, driverless cars promise real value to these age groups in particular.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: When you look at attitudes toward driverless cars, there doesn't seem to be a clear generational divide.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: This is especially interesting when you consider that younger people are generally more interested in travelrelated technologies than older onesWhen it comes to driverless cars, differences in attitude are more pronounced based on factors not related to age.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: The public overall is spilt on whether they'd like to use a driverless car.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: Once driverless cars are actually for sale, the early adopters will be the people who can afford to buy them.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: Older adults, especially those with limited mobility or difficulty driving on their own, are one of the classic use-cases for driverless cars.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: Not everyone wants a driverless car now—and no one can get one yet—but among those who are open to them, every age group is similarly engaged.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: More people who lived in cities and suburbs said they wanted to try driverless cars than those who lived in rural areasWhile there's reason to believe that interest in self-driving cars is going up across the board, a person's age will have little to do with how self-driving cars can become mainstream.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: It may start a revolution in the car industry.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: In a study last year, of all people surveyed, 48 percent said they wanted to ride in one, while 50 percent did notThe fact that attitudes toward self-driving cars appear to be so steady across generations suggests how transformative the shift to driverless cars could be.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文

Sentence.sentence: College graduates, for example, are particularly interested in driverless cars compared with those who have less education: 59 percent of college graduates said they would like to use a driverless car compared with 38 percent of those with a high-school diploma or lessWhere a person lives matters, toIt will not necessarily reduce road accidents.
Sentence.come: 出自-2016年6月阅读原文
